title: Bayes' Theorem
text: The probability of event A given event B may be computed by means of the following formula: P(A$$\mid$$B)=P(A)P(B$$\mid$$A)/P(B)

title: Events
text: Let A denote the event 'both children are boys' and C denote 'at least one of their children is a boy.' Then P(A$$\mid$$C)=P(A)P(C$$\mid$$A)/P(C)

title: P(A)
text: What is the probability that both children are boys, without knowing whether the first child is a boy or a girl? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(A)
subHints.text: There are four possible outcomes: BB, BG, GB, or GG (where B is boy and G is girl). Both children are boys in only 1 out of the 4 possible outcomes, so P(A) is $$\frac{1}{4}$$

title: P(C$$\mid$$A)
text: What is the probability that at least one of their children is a boy given that both children are boys?

subHints.title: P(C$$\mid$$A)
subHints.text: Given that both children are boys, the only possible outcome is BB. At least one of their children is a boy in this outcome, so P(B$$\mid$$A) is $$\frac{1}{1}$$, or 1

title: P(C)
text: What is the probability that at least one of their children is a boy, without knowing that one of their children is a boy? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(C)
subHints.text: There are four possible outcomes: BB, BG, GB, or GG (where B is boy and G is girl). The at least one child is a boy in 3 out of the 4 possible outcomes, so P(C) is $$\frac{3}{4}$$

title: P(A$$\mid$$C)
text: Use P(A), P(C$$\mid$$A), and P(C) to solve for P(A$$\mid$$C) using Bayes' Theorem
